sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Handwritten letter from Schenker to Cube, dated October 26, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Acknowledges OC 9/34, [42], and its contents; comments on the "youth of today" – organic connection is the best thing for them; asks publisher of Schäfke book. Once Der freie Satz is in print, he will give his mind to the continuation of the Urlinie-Tafeln. Schenker's name is included in the Spanish Enciclicopedia universale.

tei:opener.tei:dateline: WienCube's annotations – "Wien" and several superscript numbers – may have indicated points for reply., 26corr.10.34
tei:opener.tei:salute: Lieber Herr Professor (1) v Cube!Writing of this letter is recorded in Schenker's diary at OJ 4/8, p. 3956, October 26, 1934: "An v. Cube (Br.): danke für den Furtwängler-Brief, für das Bildchen; bitte um Angabe des Verlages von Schäfke, empfehle der Ueberheblichkeit der Jugend entgegenzutreten, den Zusammenhang ausrufen, predigen!" ("To von Cube (letter): thank him for the Furtwängler letter, for the little graph; ask for details of the publisher of Schäfke, recommend confronting the arrogance of today's youth and proclaiming, preaching connection!").

tei:div.tei:p:
für Ihren inhaltsreichen Brief meinen wärmsten Dank.OJ 9/34, [42], October 4, 1934, in which Cube had copied a letter from Furtwängler in full, and enclosed a photograph of his wife and son. Dank für die Abschrift des Furtw-Brief (2) an Sie, (2) für das schöne Bildchen Ihrer Gattin u. des Jungen u. die wichtigen Mitteilungen. Daß Sie doch einen Wirkungskreis erreicht haben, (3) freut mich aufrichtig, soll auch Sie freuen, denn wir leben in einer Zeit, wo ein HubermannBronislaw Huberman (1882–1947), violinist, widely regarded as one of the most original concert artists of the twentieth century. im Meisterkurs nur 3 Schüler hat! Die Menschheit ist aus der Musik „ausgetreten“, wie sie aus Kirchen u. Konfessionen „auszutreten“ pflegt. Die neue Jugend
will u. kann des Segens nicht froh werden, ein solches stolze Erbe angetreten zu haben, sie will selbst in Genie, Offenbarung u. Intuition „machen“ – wie ratzekahl wird sie als Erblasserin dastehen! Ist nicht die Aufgabe durchaus neu, gerade einer neuen Jugend würdig, endlich die Offenbarungen der Genies sich zu eigen zu machen, um der Kunst u. der Menschheit zu dienen? Doch nein – lieber nichts machen, lieber schlecht, wenn nur endlich jene Großen beiseite geschafft werden!

Die Jugend verstünde heute nur die Lehre, die sie über Nacht befähigte, die X. Sinf. Beethovens’, die V. Brahms’ u. noch viel besseres zu schreiben – sonst gilt ihr kein Unterricht was. Ach, sie ist so papageno-bescheiden,i.e. "carefree as a bird." In The Magic Flute, the character of Papageno represents life without great ambition or effort. sie will, „nur“ das, „nur“ jenes, u. wie sie überzeugt ist, nie zu viel ... (?!)

Am besten ist, man brächte sie doch mindestens dazu, das Wunder des „organischen Zusammenhanges“ in der Musik zu erleben oder zu glauben, das allein wäre schon der größte Erfolg, der heute erzielt werden kann! Ihre Komponiersorgen oder -freuden mag sie dann selber austragen, vor Allem lerne sie die Großen bekennen!
Prof. Violin habe ich mit Ihrem Briefe bekannt gemacht.

Können Sie mir den Verlag des Buches von SchäfkeIn his previous letter (OJ 9/34, [42], October 4, 1934), Cube had mentioned that Schenker's work was favourably cited in Rudolf Schäfke's Geschichte der Musikästhetik in Umrissen (Berlin: Max Hesse, 1934). nennen? Ich wäre Ihnen sehr dankbar, wenn Sie es täten.

Mit Ihren Gedanken über weitere Zusammenhänge von Natur u. Kunst mich gründlicher zu befassen, fehlt mir eine genaue Vorlage (2) 3 u. augenblicklich die Zeit, da ich Druck
und Stich durchzuführen habe.Schenker is referring to Cube's ideas on diatonic systems and their analogue in geometry, as outlined in previous letters and characterized in OJ 9/34, [42], October 4, 1934, as a development of his teacher's theory of modal mixture in Harmonielehre. Schenker had not responded to an earlier letter on the subject, and now cites the pressure of completing the corrections to Der freie Satz. Erst bis der „fr. S“ (5) 4 erschienen sein wird, kann ich an die Herausgabe des II Url.heftes (6) 5 denken: Beeth. Son. cism (ganz), Moz. Fant. dm (ganz), Chop. Et. 10III, Brahms „Auf dem Kirchhof“, usw. usw. (7) 6
Except for the Mozart Fantasia, all these works appear in Schenker's handwritten list of works to be analyzed in a planned continuation of his Fünf Urlinie-Tafeln (New York: David Mannes Music School, 1932). The continuation was never published: see Felix Salzer's Introduction, with Schenker's handwritten list reproduced, to Schenker, Five Graphic Music Analyses (New York: Dover Publications, 1969), pp. 17–21. The list is given previously in Schenker's letter to Cube OJ 5/7a, [49], May 8, 1934, and the three instrumental works are also listed in Schenker's letter to Jonas, OJ 5/18, 49, August 2, 1934.

Beste Wünsche für Ihren Kurs!In his previous letter, OJ 9/34, [42], October 4, 1934, Cube had informed his former teacher that he had been offered the opportunity to teach a semester-long course at a music school in Hamburg.

tei:closer.tei:salute: Herzliche Grüße Ihnen u. Ihrer Gattin

tei:postscript.tei:p: Vielleicht freut es Sie zu hören, daß nun auch die spanische Enzyklopedia universale (Madrid)Schenker informs Jonas of this entry ten days earlier, OJ 5/18, 59, October 16, 1934. The Enciclopedia universale ilustrada europeo-americana, the largest of its kind in the world, was published in 70 numbered volumes between 1908 and 1930. The entry "Schenker (Enrique)" in vol. 54 (1927), p. 972, describes him as a "compositor y musicógrafo austriaco contemporáneoW and credits him as much for his compositions ("diversas obras para piano, estudios, fantasias, unas Danzas sirias y melodías vocales") as for his writings, of which only some of the earlier volumes are listed:"Ensayo sobre la novena sinfonía, Kontrapunkt, Harmonielehre y Neue Musikalische Theorien und Phantasien.” meinen Namen aufgenommen hat.

tei:div.tei:p:
My warmest thanks for your informative letter. Thanks for the copy of Furtwängler's letter (2) to you, (2) for the lovely picture of your wife and the young boy, and the important communications. That you have, after all, succeded in finding a place in which to work (3) genuinely pleases me; it should also please you, for we live at a time when a Hubermann has only three pupils in his master class! Humanity has "left" music, the way it is accustomed to "leaving" the church and confession. The new youth
do not want and are unable to rejoice in the blessing of having inherited such a proud inheritance; they want to "make it" for themselves in genius, revelation and intuition – how dearly would they write its last will and testament. Is not the task entirely new, worthy precisely of a new generation of youth, the task of finally making the revelations of the geniuses their own, to serve art and humanity? But no – they would rather do nothing, or do it badly: if only those great ones were finally pushed aside!

The youth of today would only understand the teachings that would enable them to write a tenth Beethoven symphony, a fifth Brahms symphony, and still even better things. Otherwise no instruction is of any use to them. Ah, they are so Papageno-like modest, they want "only" this, "only" that, and , as they are convinced, never too much ... (?!)

The best thing is that one at least gets them to experience, or believe, the wonder of "organic connection" in music; that alone would already be the greatest triumph that can be reached today! Their concerns, or joys, in composing are something they can fulfill themselves; above all, they should learn to respect the great composers!
I have made known to Professor Violin the content of your letter.
Can you tell me the name of the publisher of Schäfke's book? I would be very grateful to you if you would do this.

I cannot deal more thoroughly with your thoughts about further connections between nature and art without a precise model (2) 3 and, at present, time, as I must go through the printing
and engraving. Only when Free Composition (5) 4 appears in print will I be able to think about the publication of the second series of Urlinien: (6) 5
Beethoven's Sonata in C minor (complete), Mozart's Fantasia in D minor (complete), Chopin's Etude Op. 10, No. 3, Brahms's "Auf dem Kirchhof", etc. etc. (7) 6

tei:closer.tei:salute: Cordial greetings to you and your wife.

tei:postscript.tei:p: P.S. It will perhaps please you to hear that now even the Spanish Enciclicopedia universale (Madrid) has included my name.
